text: Introduction: Indeed, all praise is due to Allah; we praise Him, seek His help, and ask for His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and the bad consequences of our deeds. Whomsoever Allah guides, none can misguide, and whomsoever He misguides, none can guide. I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, having no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His slave and Messenger. {O you who have believed, fear Allah as He should be feared and do not die except as Muslims} [Al Imran: 102], {O mankind, fear your Lord, who created you from one soul and created from it its mate and dispersed from both of them many men and women. And fear Allah, through whom you ask one another, and the wombs. Indeed Allah is ever, over you, an Observer} [An-Nisa: 1], {O you who have believed, fear Allah and speak words of appropriate justice (70) He will amend for you your deeds and forgive you your sins. And whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger has certainly attained a great attainment} [Al-Ahzab: 70-71] (1). Since the human body is susceptible to the falling of something from its skin or organs, whether intentionally or unintentionally, and a person may be born with an extra part such as an extra finger on the foot or hand, the ruling regarding these separated or extra things—in terms of amputation, washing, praying over them, burial, and other rulings—becomes confusing for the Muslim. Therefore, I desired to research the jurisprudential rulings regarding separated parts in some detail, given that I have not seen independent research collecting the rulings specific to them. I have titled it (Fiqh Rulings Related to Extra, Separated, and Amputated Parts of the Human Body). Importance of the Topic: The importance of the topic is evident through the following points: First: People's need for clarification of these rulings related to amputated human organs.

text: Research Summary: 1/ That separated human parts and organs are generally pure (Tahir) according to the preponderant view. 2/ It is obligatory to bury separated parts that contain life, such as a hand and a finger. 3/ It is better (Mustahabb) to bury separated parts that do not contain life, such as hair, as a form of honoring. 4/ It is permissible, according to the preponderant view, to replant an organ severed in cases other than Hadd or Qisas. 5/ It is permissible to amputate and cut extra organs out of necessity and need. 6/ It is not permissible to amputate and cut extra organs for improvement and beautification. 7/ It is not permissible to sell human organs according to the preponderant view, in order to preserve human dignity.

text: Preamble: Honoring the Human Being in Islamic Sharia. Many texts indicate Allah's honoring of the Children of Adam and His preference for them over many of His creations. The Almighty said: {And We have certainly honored the children of Adam and carried them on the land and sea and provided for them of the good things and preferred them over much of what We have created, with [definite] preference} (1). In Sahih Muslim, on the authority of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him), he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Do not envy one another, do not artificially inflate prices, do not hate one another, do not turn away from one another, and do not undercut one another in trade, but be servants of Allah and brothers. A Muslim is the brother of a Muslim: he does not oppress him, nor does he fail him, nor does he despise him. Piety (Taqwa) is right here"—and he pointed to his chest three times—"It is enough evil for a man to despise his Muslim brother. All of a Muslim is sacred to a Muslim: his blood, his wealth, and his honor" (2). This Hadith indicates manners and virtues for good interaction between Muslims and clarifies the sanctity of a Muslim's blood, wealth, and honor. Therefore, one of the objectives of Islamic Sharia is protecting the five necessities (Religion, Life, Honor/Lineage, Wealth, and Intellect) (3). Islam also observed the sanctity of a Muslim whether alive or dead, so texts came prohibiting the breaking of a dead person's bones, prohibiting harming him, and prohibiting stepping on his grave, among other texts indicating his honoring. From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her), the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Breaking the bone of the dead is like breaking it while he is alive" (4).

But of the people is he who disputes about Allah without knowledge or guidance or an enlightening Book} (2). Requirement One: Definition of Parts, Separation, and Amputation. Parts (Ajza') linguistically: Plural of Juz', and the Juz' is a portion of a thing. It is masculine. It is said: 'I took a part of it', meaning: I took a portion of it and isolated it (3). Separation (Infisal) linguistically: Detachment. It is said: 'He separated the thing, so it separated', meaning he cut it, so it was cut off. It is the opposite of connection (4). Amputation (Batr) linguistically: 'He batara the thing', meaning he cut it. Every cut is a batr. From it is a 'batir' sword, meaning sharp/cutting. It is said: 'He amputated the tail or the organ' if he cut it and removed it. It is also applied to cutting a thing before completion (5). It has been used terminologically with these two meanings by the jurists, and it may be applied to any cutting. text: Requirement Two: Ablution (Wudu) of the Amputee. The jurists of the four schools of thought (1) agreed that the owner of an amputated limb must wash what remains of his limb. For example, regarding the ablution of one whose hand was cut off from the wrist joint (Rusgh) (2), he must wash the remaining obligatory part of his arm. And one whose toes were cut off must wash the remainder. It is stated in Al-Durr Al-Mukhtar (3): [He said in Al-Bahr: If his hand or foot is cut off and nothing remains of the elbow and ankle, washing drops. If it remains, it is obligatory]. And in Mawahib Al-Jalil (4): [If part of the obligatory site is cut off, washing what remains of it is obligatory without disagreement]. And in Al-Siraj Al-Wahhaj (5): [Likewise, washing the healthy part of the remaining ailing limb is obligatory according to the Madhab]. And in Al-Insaf (6): [If anything remains of the obligatory site, washing it is obligatory without dispute]. They reasoned with the following: First Evidence: The Almighty’s saying: {So fear Allah as much as you are able} (7), and the Almighty’s saying: {Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity} (8).

text: Point of Reference: It implies that washing the remainder of the limb is obligatory because that is within a human's ability, without burden or hardship. Second Evidence: The Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) containing the Prophet's (peace be upon him) saying: "...and if I order you to do something, then do of it as much as you can" (1). Point of Reference: Commands are based on ability and capacity. Whoever can do part of the commanded act but is unable to do the rest, it is obligatory for him to do it. It is not permissible to abandon the whole due to the claim of inability to do the part. Rather, the accountable person must do what he is capable of, because ability to perform the act is a condition for accountability. The command that the accountable person can do and is capable of does not drop due to what he is incapacitated from or what is difficult for him to do (2). Third Evidence: Consensus (Ijma), which is one of the strongest proofs (3). Lack of disagreement was reported by Al-Hattab and Al-Mardawi (4) as mentioned earlier in the beginning of the requirement. Fourth Evidence: The Fiqh Maxim [The easy is not waived by the difficult] (5). The meaning of this maxim: [The command that the accountable person can do, and which is easy for him, does not drop due to what is difficult for him to do or becomes hard] (6). Also, the Shafi'is and Hanbalis (7) see that it is recommended (Mustahabb) to wash the rest of the limb, even if it was cut from above the obligatory point. So whoever had his hand cut off including the elbow, it is recommended for him to wash the upper arm ( عضد), and whoever had his leg cut off including the ankle, it is recommended for him to wash the shin. They have justifications, including: First: So that the limb is not left without purification.

text: Its meaning: [That which follows another in existence does not stand alone in ruling; rather, it enters into the ruling with what it follows]. The intended meaning of 'follower' here: What does not exist independently by itself, but its existence follows the existence of another; thus its ruling is not separated from the ruling of what it follows (1). In this requirement, the ease of Sharia and the tolerance of the religion become clear, and that its rulings are based on removing hardship from the accountable person, and that the Muslim does what he can, and Allah does not burden a soul beyond its capacity, and that with hardship comes ease. Requirement Three: Ruling on Separated Parts in terms of Purity and Impurity. This issue is based on the disagreement regarding the dead human body in terms of purity and impurity. Therefore, jurists differed regarding separated parts in terms of their essence (purity and impurity) into three opinions: First Opinion: That separated parts from the human body are absolutely pure (Tahir). This is the opinion of the general body of jurists, the relied-upon view of the Malikis, the correct view of the Shafi'is, the Madhab of the Hanbalis, and the saying of Ata' bin Abi Rabah, Ata' Al-Khurasani. It is the choice of Abu Bakr from the Hanbalis, Al-Bukhari, Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, Ibn Rajab, Ibn Hajar, Al-Shawkani (2), and others. It is stated in Minah Al-Jalil (3): [So what is separated from a living or dead human is pure according to the relied-upon view]. And in Mughni Al-Muhtaj (4): [So what is separated from a human, fish, or locust is pure].

text: Al-Mardawi said (1): [If his tooth falls out and he puts it back while it is still warm and it sets, it is pure. This is the Madhab, and the majority are upon it, and most of them stated it definitively...]. It is stated in Al-Rawd Al-Murbi' (2): [And what falls from him - meaning a human - such as an organ or tooth, is pure]. They cited evidences including: First Evidence: {And We have certainly honored the children of Adam and carried them on the land and sea and provided for them of the good things and preferred them over much of what We have created, with [definite] preference} (3). Point of Reference: That the view of purity is what aligns with the verse and the texts reported regarding his honoring (4). Second Evidence: The Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) threw the Jamrah, slaughtered his sacrifice, and shaved, he handed the shaver his right side and he shaved it. Then he called Abu Talha Al-Ansari and gave it to him. Then he handed him the left side and said: 'Shave,' so he shaved it, and he gave it to Abu Talha and said: 'Distribute it among the people'" (5). Point of Reference: Had it not been pure, the Prophet (peace be upon him) would not have distributed it among the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them). It was argued: This is specific to the Prophet (peace be upon him). It was answered: The principle is that the Prophet (peace be upon him) shares rulings with his Ummah, except for what evidence indicates is specific to him, and there is no evidence here, so the ruling remains general. Third Evidence: The Hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "...Indeed, the believer does not become impure" (6).

text: Fourth Evidence: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Do not treat your dead as impure, for the Muslim does not become impure, alive or dead" (1). Point of Reference: The believer is pure alive and dead, whether connected to him or separated from him, due to the generality of the Hadiths. Fifth Evidence: What the Prophet (peace be upon him) did when he returned the eye of Qatadah bin Al-Nu'man (may Allah be pleased with him) when he was injured on the day of Uhud, and he put it back in its place (2). Point of Reference: That the separated part of the body is pure; if it were impure, the Prophet (peace be upon him) would not have returned the eye of Qatadah bin Al-Nu'man (may Allah be pleased with him). Sixth Evidence: The Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: While a man was standing at Arafat, he fell from his mount and it broke his neck - or he said: it killed him (3) - The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Wash him with water and sidr (lote tree leaves), and shroud him in two garments, and do not embalm him, and do not cover his head (4), for he will be resurrected on the Day of Judgment reciting Talbiyah" (5). Point of Reference: Had he been impure, washing would not have been beneficial for him. Also, washing is a form of honoring and cleanliness. Seventh Evidence: The opinion stating the impurity of what separates from the human body involves difficulty and hardship, and it is difficult for people to avoid it due to the frequency of what falls from him and the widespread nature of the issue (Ummum al-Balwa).

text: And Islamic Sharia came to remove difficulty, hardship, and distress. The Almighty said: {And He has not placed upon you in the religion any difficulty} (1), and His saying: {Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you hardship} (2). Second Opinion: That the separated part of the human body is absolutely impure (Najis). This is the view of Muhammad bin Al-Hasan from the Hanafis (3), a view in the Maliki Madhab (4), the relied-upon view of the Shafi'is (5), and a narration from Ahmad (6). Al-Shafi'i said in Al-Umm (7): [If a woman's bone is broken and flies off, she may not patch it except with the bone of an animal whose meat is eaten and was slaughtered Islamically. Likewise, if a tooth falls out, it becomes dead (Maitah), so he may not put it back after it has separated]. Al-Nawawi said in Al-Majmu' (8): [As for if a part of his body separates, such as his hand or nail, the Iraqis, or the majority of them, affirmed its impurity...]. In Al-Insaf (9): (As for separated human hair, the correct view of the Madhab, upon which are the As-hab, is its purity; many of them stated it definitively. And from him [Ahmad] is a narration of its impurity, other than the hair of the Prophet (peace be upon him)). They reason with the following: First Evidence: The noble verse {Say, "I do not find within that which was revealed to me [anything] forbidden to one who would eat it unless it be a dead animal or blood spilled out or the flesh of swine - for indeed, it is impure - or it be [that slaughtered in] disobedience, dedicated to other than Allah} (10).

text: Point of Inference: The verse is general and includes human dead bodies and others, so it would be impure upon separation. It is discussed: That what is meant is what comes out of animals while they are alive, and what comes out of the jugular veins at slaughter (1). Also, what is meant by it is animals, and humans are not measured against animals in rulings. Second Evidence: The Hadith of Abu Waqid (may Allah be pleased with him), containing his saying (peace be upon him): "Whatever is cut from a beast (Bahimah) while it is alive is dead (Maitah)" (2). Point of Reference: That what is cut from a human while alive is impure; because the dead human body is impure as evidenced by washing it after death. Even if it was revealed for a specific cause, the correct view is that consideration is given to the generality of the wording, not the specificity of the cause, as in the verses of Li'an (imprecation) and Zihar, which were revealed for specific causes but their generality remained for the rest of the Ummah (3). It is answered by the following: That a human is not called a 'beast' (Bahimah), and this Hadith is restricted by its wording and cause to beasts, so it does not extend to others. Also, what is meant is the dead animal, as evidenced by the jurists citing this Hadith in the chapters of Hunting, Slaughter, and Purity (4). This is supported by the occasion on which this Hadith was narrated, where Abu Waqid (may Allah be pleased with him) said: The people in the Jahiliyyah (pre-Islamic period) used to cut off camel humps and cut off sheep tails and eat them, and carry the fat from them. When the Prophet (peace be upon him) arrived, they asked him about that, so he said: "Whatever is cut from a beast while it is alive...

text: ...is dead (Maitah)" (1). As for washing him after his death, it is intended for cleanliness and perfection, not purification from impurity. Ibn Al-Arabi refuted those who said it is dead (Maitah) and impure, saying: [This is a clear mistake. Whoever it was hidden from him that returning it and its return to its form necessitates the return of its ruling is ignorant; because the impurity was in it due to separation, and it has returned connected. Rulings of Sharia are not attributes of substances, but rather they are rulings returning to Allah's saying about them and His informing about them] (2). Modern medicine has also proven that some organs retain life for a known period even after the death of their owner (3), so by this, these organs are judged not to be impure because life remains in them. Third Opinion: Differentiating between what separated from the human body (4): if it contains life and blood, like a hand, nose, and ear, they say it is impure. And what does not contain life or blood, like hair and nails, they judge as pure. This is the relied-upon opinion among the Hanafis, an opinion among the Shafi'is, and a narration in the Madhab of Ahmad (5).

text: It is stated in Bada'i' Al-Sana'i' (1): [As for that which has flowing blood, there is no disagreement regarding the parts that contain blood such as flesh, fat, skin, and the like, that they are impure; due to the retention of impure blood in them, which is spilled blood]. It is stated in Al-Durr Al-Mukhtar (2): [What is separated from the living, if it is a part containing blood like a hand, ear, nose, and the like, is impure by Consensus (3). Otherwise, like hair and nail, it is pure according to us]. And in Al-Mughni: [Because it is hair; the connected part is pure, so the separated part is pure, like the hair of all animals. We say the same regarding human organs. Even if we accept their impurity, they become impure like other animals by separation during life, unlike hair] (4). The secret of the difference in ruling: That life in wool and hair is a life of growth, like the life of trees and palms, not a life of soul (spirit), as they do not feel pain when cut or clipped, unlike bone and flesh, for theirs is a life of soul, evidenced by pain upon breaking or cutting. The evidence that wool and hair are pure upon separation is the Almighty's saying: {And from their wool, fur, and hair is furnishing and enjoyment for a time} (5), where it came in the context of gratitude/favor, and favor is not granted with something impure. The verse encompasses the state of life and death (6). Also, evidence indicates that bone and flesh are impure upon cutting and separation. The Almighty said: {And he presents for Us an example and forgets his [own] creation. He says, "Who will give life to bones while they are disintegrated?"} (7). This indicates that...

text: ...they had a soul and life during life, so they became impure by death. They inferred with the proofs of the first opinion for purity, limiting it to what has no soul, life, or sensation. And they inferred with the proofs of the second opinion for impurity, limiting it to what has life and soul. Weighting (Tarjih): The preponderant view is the first opinion, the opinion of the majority, which is the general purity of what separates from the human body, whether the separated part has life or not; due to the following: The strength of the evidences they cited. Its agreement with general texts on honoring the human. Its agreement with tolerance, ease, and removing hardship from the accountable person. And due to the discussions raised against the proofs of the other opinions (1). Requirement Four: Ruling on Separated Parts in terms of Burial or Disposal. Human body parts are divided into two categories: First Category: That which has sanctity and contains life and blood, and originally should not be removed, like a hand and a leg. This must be buried to honor the human body. Al-Bahuti said (2): [If part of a confirmed dead person is found, other than hair, nail, and tooth, it is washed, shrouded, prayed over, and buried obligatorily. Then if the rest is found, it is prayed over and buried beside it]. In Requirement Five, quotes from jurists regarding the sanctity and dignity of these parts and whether they are prayed over will follow. Second Category: That which has no life or blood, like hair and nail. It has been reported from the jurists of the four schools that it is recommended (Mustahabb) to bury what separated from the body and that it is better, while remaining permissible to dispose of it without burial (3).

text: Ibn Nujaym said (1): [It is recommended to bury his hair... and if the hair is thrown away, there is no harm, but throwing it in the latrine (2) and washing place is disliked; because that causes disease]. Al-Qurtubi said (3): [Since the body of a believer has sanctity, preserving the sanctity of what falls and is removed from it remains. It is incumbent upon him to bury it, just as if he died, he would be buried. So if part of him dies, his sanctity is also established by burying it, so it does not disperse or fall into fire or dirty trash heaps. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) ordered burying his blood where he was cupped, so dogs would not search for it]. Al-Nawawi said (4): [Burial is not exclusive to the organ of one known to be dead; rather, everything that separates from the living, such as a limb, hair, nail, and other parts, is recommended to be buried. Likewise, the blood clot (Alaqah) and lump of flesh (Mudghah) cast by a woman are buried, as are blood from phlebotomy and cupping]. Ibn Qudamah said (5): [It is recommended to bury what he clipped of his nails or removed of his hair]. Muhanna said: I asked Ahmad about a man who takes from his hair and nails, should he bury it or throw it? He said: He buries it. I said: Did something reach you regarding it? He said: Ibn Umar used to bury it (6). They reasoned with the following evidences: First Evidence: The generality of the Almighty's saying: {Have We not made the earth a container (25) Of the living and the dead?} (7). Kifata (container): Meaning a gatherer that gathers the living on its back and the dead in its belly (8).

text: Point of Inference: That the verse indicates hiding the dead and burying him, and burying his hair and all that he removes from himself (1). Second Evidence: The Hadiths and Athar reported, including: First: From Abdul Jabbar bin Abbas, from a man of Bani Hashim, that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him): "Ordered the burial of hair, nail, and blood" (4). Second: From Abdul Jabbar bin Wa'il, from his father, from the Prophet (peace be upon him): "He used to order the burial of hair and nails" (5). Fourth: From Nafi', from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them), he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Bury the nails, hair, and blood, for they are dead (Maitah)" (7). Even if they are weak, they may rise to the level of Hasan (good) by the sum of their chains. text: Third Evidence: That burying them prevents using them for harm, as sorcerers do, as the Prophet (peace be upon him) was bewitched in a comb and combings (hairfall) (1). Fourth Evidence: That Islam is the religion of cleanliness and integrity, and it has commanded removing harm. There is no doubt that burying hair and nails is perfection of cleanliness, and it also involves consideration for the feelings of others, which is what Islam calls for. Requirement Five: The outcome of separated body parts in terms of praying over them, containing two issues: First Issue: That the owner of the severed organ is alive: The amputated and separated organ, while its owner is alive, is not washed and not prayed over. This is a point of agreement among the jurists of the schools, especially if it is less than half, or a single organ like a leg or a hand (2). The Permanent Committee for Scholarly Research and Ifta in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia issued a Fatwa to this effect (3). It is stated in Maraqi Al-Falah (4): [If most of the body is found, or half of it with the head, it is washed and prayed over; otherwise, no]. Al-Hattab said (5): [As for the dismembered body, if all of it or most of it is gathered, it is washed and prayed over]. It is understood from the saying of the author of Al-Maraqi and from Al-Hattab's words also that what was a separated organ is not washed nor prayed over.

text: Al-Nawawi said (1): [...There is no disagreement that the hand cut off in theft and Qisas is not washed nor prayed over, but it is wrapped in a cloth and buried. Likewise, clipped nails and hair taken from the living; none of it is prayed over, but it is recommended to bury them]. Al-Mardawi said (2): [What separated from a living person, like a hand and leg that separated at a time—if the whole body were found [in that state] it would not be washed nor prayed over—according to the correct view of the Madhab]. Second Issue: That the owner of the severed part is dead. This issue has two cases: First Case: That organs and parts of a dead person are found separated from him, like a hand, leg, or others. If they are found separated, and the rest of the body is found, they are washed and placed in his shroud, and the body and what separated from it are prayed over all at once. Ibn Qudamah reported agreement on that, saying: [If something falls from the dead, it is washed and placed with him in his shrouds. The summary is that if something separates from the dead and is present, it is washed and placed with him in his shrouds. Ibn Sirin said this, and we do not know any disagreement regarding it] (3). Second Case: That the severed organ is found without the rest of the body. If the part is found separated, the scholars (may Allah have mercy on them) differed regarding praying over this organ into three opinions: First Opinion: That praying over it is not legislated. Rather, prayer is offered for the greater part of the dead person; even if half of him is found complete, he is not prayed over; it must be more than the dead person [to be prayed over]. This is the saying of the Hanafis (4).

text: Al-Kasani said (1): [And prayer is not offered over a part of a human until the majority of him is found according to us; because if we prayed over this part, it would obligate us to pray over the remainder if we found it, leading to repetition]. Ibn Al-Humam said (2): [If limbs of a dead person or part of his body are found, they are not washed nor prayed over, but buried; unless more than half of his body is found, then he is washed and prayed over. Or if half is found along with the head, then he is prayed over. If he was split into two halves lengthwise and one half was found, it is not washed nor prayed over]. They reasoned and argued with the following: First Evidence: That what is established from the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace be upon him) is praying over dead people with their complete bodies, and it was not reported that the Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed over part of a body. The principle is adhering to the text (3). Second Evidence: That what is less than half is appended to hair and nail. It is discussed: That nails and hair have no life in them, so what has life cannot be measured against them. Second Opinion: The Malikis hold that it is not prayed over unless two-thirds or more are found, or half or more. If less than two-thirds but with the head, it is prayed over (4). Al-Dardir said (5): [And he is not washed if less than the 'Jull' - meaning less than two-thirds of the body - and the intended meaning of 'body' is other than the head. So if half the body is found, or more, but less than two-thirds with the head, he is not washed according to the relied-upon view; i.e., it is disliked, because the condition for washing is the presence of the deceased. If part of him is found, the ruling is for the majority/dominant part, and there is no ruling for the minor part].

text: Third Evidence: The sanctity of a part is like the sanctity of the whole, especially if that part was a locus of life. If a part of him is gone, the sanctity of what remains is not gone, and one must perform upon what remains of his body the washing, prayer, and burial, as is the Sunnah for the dead (1). Al-Qurtubi said (2): [The body of a believer has sanctity; so whatever falls from it or is removed from it, its protection from violation remains standing. It is a duty to bury it, just as if he had died he would be buried. So if a part of him dies, his sanctity is likewise established by burying it, so that it does not scatter or fall into fire or into filthy dumps]. The most correct view—and Allah knows best—is according to the following detail: 1 - If the amputated limb belongs to a deceased person who has already been prayed over, it is washed, shrouded, and buried, but it is not prayed over again, as the prayer over his whole suffices for the prayer over a part of him. 2 - If the severed limb belongs to a deceased person who was not prayed over due to his body being lost, or torn apart in a way that it could not be gathered, then the limb is washed, shrouded, prayed over, and buried (3). 3 - If the separated limb belongs to a deceased person who has not been prayed over, and the rest of his body is present, it is placed with the rest of his body so that prayer is performed over all his parts in a single prayer. 4 - If the limb belongs to a living person, it is shrouded and then buried, but it is not prayed over, because praying over the separated limb would result in praying over him twice. In this topic, the sanctity of the believer and his dignity before Allah becomes clear, as well as the comprehensiveness of the rulings of the religion and their suitability for every time and place. Furthermore, a human must generally protect himself, and his limbs specifically, as this falls under the five necessities that the Sharia came to preserve and maintain.

text: Requirement Six: The ruling on transplanting organs back into the owner's body after they have been severed. This contains two issues: Issue One: Transplanting an organ severed in a situation other than Hadd (fixed punishment) or Qisas (retribution). Issue Two: Transplanting an organ severed in a Hadd or Qisas. A human may suffer the amputation of one of his limbs, such as a hand, finger, leg, ear, or otherwise, due to a traffic accident, a fall from a high place, or due to modern machinery in factories. Alternatively, the amputation may be due to a Hadd from the Hudud, such as for theft or banditry (Hirabah), or for any criminal cause. Modern medicine has—by the grace of Allah—reached the ability to restore the organ after its excision and amputation by suturing nerves and tendons and connecting blood vessels, provided there is no long time lapse, no contamination, and no tearing in a way that prevents its restoration (1). Therefore, scholars have differentiated between what was cut in a Hadd or Qisas, to which a private right is attached, and what was separated due to an accident of time, to which no one's right is attached. This is what we will address in this requirement as follows: Issue One: Transplanting an organ severed in a situation other than Hadd or Qisas. Jurists differed regarding this amputated limb in terms of its transplantation and restoration to its place. The cause of the difference is the purity or impurity of the limb after its separation. Those who said it is pure permitted its restoration and transplantation into its owner's body, and those who said it is impure prevented that. Some distinguished between human parts: some have life, sensation, and blood attached to them, like a hand or leg, while other human parts do not have life attached, like a tooth. text: Preponderance: The most correct view—and Allah the Exalted is Higher and knows best—is the first view, which is the view of the purity of the amputated and separated organ. Based on this, it is permissible to restore and transplant it again, for the following matters: 1 - Due to the strength of their evidence. 2 - Its agreement with the objectives of the Sharia in removing hardship and facilitating for the accountable. 3 - That it involves applying the rules of Fiqh by committing the lesser of two harms. 4 - Due to the refutations raised against the evidence of the other views (1). Issue Two: Transplanting an organ severed in a Hadd or Qisas. Perhaps it is appropriate, before mentioning the disagreement in this issue, to mention the legal objectives (Maqasid) upon which the legal ruling is built. Jurists have mentioned legal maxims and Sharia objectives related to Hudud and Qisas, the most prominent of which perhaps are the following: First: The primary objective of Hudud and Qisas is the preservation of the five necessities (Religion, Intellect, Life, Lineage/Honor, and Wealth). Second: Deterrence and restraint for the criminal himself, and for anyone whose soul tempts him to commit the crime. Third: Purifying the criminal from the sin. Fourth: Satisfying the victim or his heirs and removing the rage from their hearts. Fifth: Establishing security and stability in the land, so society lives in comfort and tranquility (2).

text: Looking at the legal evidence and the observed objectives, scholars have differed regarding transplanting a severed organ where the cause of amputation was Hadd or Qisas, into two views: The First View: Permissibility. This was said by Al-Shafi'i, Ibn Rushd of the Malikis, and it is a view in the Hanbali school preferred by Ibn Qudamah, and chosen by Wahbah Al-Zuhayli (1). Ibn Rushd said: [If retribution is exacted after they returned to their original state, so the ear or eye of the one retaliated against returned, then that is that. If they did not return, and the tooth or ear of the first one had returned, he has no claim. If the tooth or ear of the one from whom retaliation was taken returned, but the tooth or ear of the first one did not return, he pays the indemnity (Aql)] (2). And he said in Al-Umm regarding the issue of the victim returning his organ to its place: [If the victim does not reattach it, or wanted to reattach it but it did not attach, and he exacted retribution from the perpetrator, and he (the perpetrator) reattached it and it attached, the perpetrator is not liable for more than it being severed from him once. If the victim asks the governor to cut it from the perpetrator a second time, the governor does not cut it for retribution (Qawad), because he has performed retribution once...] (3). Ibn Qudamah said: [If a person's ear is cut off, and retribution is taken from him (the perpetrator), and the perpetrator reattaches his ear and it sticks, and the victim demands its removal, he does not have that right... and the retribution has been fulfilled, so no right remains for him against him... And the ruling for the tooth is like the ruling for the ear] (4). They argued with evidence including: First Evidence: That this is consistent with removing hardship which the Sharia came with. {And He has not placed upon you in the religion any difficulty} (5) and His saying: {Allah does not intend to make for you any difficulty} (6).

Manner of Deduction: That the command for cauterization is evidence of the prohibition of restoring it. It is answered: That cauterization was prescribed as a mercy to him, so that the wound does not hemorrhage blood causing him to die. text: Manner of Deduction: Hanging the thief's hand on his neck is a legal ruling considered part of the completion of the punishment and the Hadd. Hudud were prescribed for the sake of rebuke, deterrence, and making an example (Nakal) for the criminal and others, and to maintain the intent of the punishment by the permanence of its effect as a lesson and warning, and to cut off the roots of crime. By this, the objectives of the Sharia are observed, and restoring it [the hand] necessitates missing that, so doing it is not permissible. It is answered: That one of the objectives of punishment is a lesson for others, and the cutting of the limb from the criminal suffices as an example and similarity to what he did, and as retribution for that. There is no evidence for a perpetual lesson; how many lessons have passed in a moment, yet their news remained a lesson throughout history (1). Fourth Evidence: That the cut organ became impure by separation, so its restoration is not permissible lest it leads to the invalidation of worship. It is answered: That whatever is severed from a living being is like its carrion (Maytah), and the carrion of a human is pure. Therefore, that organ which was severed must be pure. We have previously mentioned in the third requirement that the correct view is the purity of organs separated from the human body (2). Ibn Al-Arabi said in response to the view of those who argued based on impurity: [This is a mistake. Whoever it was hidden from him was ignorant that returning it and its return to its form does not necessitate its return to its ruling, because the impurity was in it due to separation, and it has returned connected. The rulings of Sharia are not a description of the substances themselves, but rather they are rulings returning to Allah's saying about them and His reporting about them] (3). Preponderance: What is preponderant—and Allah knows best—is the second view, which is the non-permissibility of restoring the organ that was severed in a Hadd or Qisas (4), for the following reasons:

text: for the removal of these excesses may be out of necessity, or their removal may be for improvement and beautification. The detail in this issue is as follows: Issue One: Cutting and removing excesses out of necessity and need. It is good to differentiate between necessity (Darurah) and need (Hajah). Necessity: It is distress and hardship at its utmost limit, such that it reaches a point where one fears destruction for himself, or approaching destruction, by the loss of his essential interests. Necessity drops the sin and imposes the guarantee (Damman/liability), as compulsion does not invalidate the right of another (1). As for Need: It is a rank lower than necessity. What is permitted by necessity is not permitted by it, except that it descends to the status of necessity regarding a single person if it is general. Need does not justify taking another's property; if someone took it, he would be sinful and liable (2). Based on that, the majority of jurists from the Hanafis, Malikis, Shafi'is, and Hanbalis (3) have gone to the view that there is no harm in removing such excesses that might harm the human, or cause hindrance in performing his function or the perfection of his performance, or cause him embarrassment in society. I have not encountered an opposing opinion. This is the choice of Ibn Jarir Al-Tabari (4), Muhammad bin Ibrahim, Ibn Baz, Ibn Uthaymeen, Muhammad Uthman Shabir, and Al-Shanqiti (5), and it is the Fatwa of the Standing Committee in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (6).

It is answered: That the disagreement concerns excesses which have no effect on disfigurement nor hindrance of work. text: That cosmetic surgery is part of the prohibited alteration. That cosmetic surgery may change realities and facts, so it enters into prohibition through the door of forgery and deception. Requirement Eight: Ruling on Selling Human Parts (1). Defining the Point of Contention: The organs of the human body differ in importance according to their functions. Also, the removal of some entails loss of life, like the heart, while a human may live with the presence of a single organ of a pair, like the kidney. What entails loss of life may not be sold, nor donated. As for what a human may live with a part of, the dispute exists among scholars. The cause of the difference returns to the following reasons: First: Absence of a correct, explicit text on the prohibition of selling organs. Second: The difference of Fatwa with the difference of time. In the past, modern and advanced medical devices did not exist in this present form, where currently the risk ratio for the donor is low or non-existent, and the success ratio of the operation for the recipient is very high (2). The First View: Non-permissibility. This is the view of the Hanafis and Shafi'is (3). Among those who chose this view are Al-Shanqiti, Ali Al-Qaradaghi, Ibn Uthaymeen, and Dr. Yusuf Al-Ahmad (4),

After that, they are damaged irreversibly. For example, kidneys remain 45 minutes, liver 8 minutes, pancreas 20 minutes, bone and cornea 24 hours. text: It is debated: That selling organs involves degradation if it is for the purpose of trade and earning. However, if it is for the purpose of saving a human, it does not contradict honoring the human. Second Evidence: The saying of the Almighty: {We have certainly created man in the best of stature} (1). Manner of Deduction: Allah created man in the best image and assigned a function for every organ in the human body, and selling them is a suspension of this function. It is debated: By not conceding the suspension of the organ's function, for it is from the perfection of Allah's creation and His power that He made man able to live with one organ of the repeated organs in the body, such as the eye or the kidney. Third Evidence: The Hadith of Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace be upon him) who said: Allah said: "Three I will be their adversary on the Day of Resurrection: A man who gave a pledge in My name then betrayed it, a man who sold a free person and consumed his price, and a man who hired an employee, fulfilled the work from him, but did not give him his wage" (2). Manner of Deduction: The Hadith indicates the prohibition of selling a free person, and if selling the whole is prohibited, selling a part is prohibited. Fourth Evidence: That body organs are not wealth (Mal), and are not the property of the human, so his disposal of them is not valid. Among the conditions for the validity of a sale is that the seller owns the item sold and it is under his disposal (3). Ibn Hazm reported the consensus of jurists on that, saying: [They agreed that a man selling what he does not own, and its owner did not authorize him, and the seller was not a ruler nor exacting a right for himself or another, nor a Mujtahid regarding property whose owner is despaired of, then it is void] (4).

Fifth Evidence: That the view of permissibility results in negative effects and various corruptions, such as trafficking in organs by the poor, or it may lead to the destruction and death of the seller of one of his organs, for the remaining organ might fail after a period, and the transplant operation might not succeed, and other potential effects. The Prophet (peace be upon him) says: (There shall be no harm and no reciprocation of harm) (2), and warding off evils takes precedence over bringing benefits, which is a legal Sharia maxim (3). The Second View: Permissibility. Those who said this include Dr. Mukhtar Al-Mahdi (4), Dr. Muhammad Naaim Yasin (5), and some medical centers (6). They argued with the following: First Evidence: That the origin in things is permissibility (Ibahah), and no explicit text has been reported regarding the prohibition of sale, so it remains on the original principle. It is answered: That the evidences are established, as in the previous evidences for the first view. Second Evidence: The Fiqh Maxim (Necessities permit prohibitions). Manner of Deduction: That it is permissible for a human to dispose by selling one of his organs when there is a need for money. It is answered: With the Fiqh Maxim (Harm is not removed by harm) which controls the maxim you used as evidence. Disposal must be within the limits of what Allah permitted, and not exceed it to others (7).

text: Third Evidence: Analogy (Qiyas) from several aspects, including: First Aspect: Analogy to the permissibility of selling human milk, and Shafi'i and Hanbali jurists have stated this (1). It is stated in Al-Hawi Al-Kabir (2): [Human milk according to us is pure, drinking it is Halal, and selling it is permissible]. Manner of Deduction: If selling milk is permissible, and it is part of a human, then selling other organs is permissible. It is answered: That this is an invalid analogy due to the existence of a difference (Fariq). Milk is renewable, and its retention harms the woman's body and health, unlike an organ. Al-Shawkani mentioned that this is among the matters cut off (definitive), saying: [The prohibition of this (i.e., selling a free person) is among the definitives of Sharia, and the consensus of the people of Islam on prohibition is known, and one does not need to deduce evidence for the likes of it] (3). Second Aspect: Analogy to the permissibility of selling a female slave and a male slave; if selling the whole is permissible, selling a part is permissible by greater reason. It is answered: That Islam looks forward to freedom and manumission, so the Sharia came with honoring the slave, not burdening him with what he cannot bear, and arranged for his manumission freedom from the Fire, as he (peace be upon him) said: (From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, who said: "Whoever frees a Muslim slave, Allah will save with every limb of him a limb of his from the Fire, even his private part for his private part") (4). Third Aspect: Analogy to the permissibility of selling the Mushaf (Quran copy), and human organs do not have greater sanctity than it.

text: Fourth Aspect: Analogy to permissibility via donation; if donation is permissible, which is a type of disposal of the organ, then selling is permissible. Third Evidence: That Islam came to preserve the human soul from destruction, which requires the view of permissibility, especially if no one is found to donate the organ. The legal Fiqh maxims support this, such as the maxim "Hardship brings facility," the maxim "Committing the lesser of two harms," the maxim "Necessity is estimated by its extent," and the maxim "Necessities permit prohibitions" (1). Preponderance: The preponderant view—and Allah knows best—is the view of non-permissibility for the following reasons: The strength of the evidence of those saying it is forbidden, along with the refutations raised against the evidence of those saying it is permissible. The consistency of the prohibition view with the spirit of the Sharia and its objectives of preserving the human soul, human dignity, and lack of vulgarity. That the view of permissibility might cause destabilization of security and lack of stability due to assaults on souls and selling their organs.

text: (Conclusion and Important Results of the Research) This brief research has been completed by the praise of Allah and His facilitation. I have benefited greatly from the words of jurists and specialists in the medical field, and reached some results, perhaps the most important of which are: (1) Allah's honoring of the children of Adam generally, and the dignity of the believer before Allah specifically. (2) Separated human parts and organs are generally pure according to the correct view. (3) The amputated organ is not prayed over if its owner is alive. (4) The amputated organ is not prayed over if its owner has been prayed over, but it is washed and buried. (5) The severed part is prayed over if the person himself was not prayed over due to loss or tearing. (6) It is not permissible to transplant an organ cut in a Hadd or Qisas according to the correct view. (7) Permissibility of transplanting an organ cut in other than a Hadd or Qisas according to the correct view. (8) Permissibility of amputating and cutting excess organs out of necessity and need. (9) It is not permissible to amputate and cut excess organs for improvement and beautification. (10) Non-permissibility of selling organs according to the correct view. (11) The Sharia came with taking means, and among that is medical treatment. (12) Inclusion of Fiqh maxims and Sharia objectives in most research issues, such as: Hardship brings facility, the maxim of committing the lesser of two harms, the maxim of necessity is estimated by its extent, the maxim of necessities permit prohibitions, and the maxim that need descends to the status of necessity whether general or specific. Recommendations: (1) Preparing specialized centers for separated human parts in hospitals and health centers, to preserve them and clarify the legal ruling related to them.
